Happy Solstice! 🙂
I have had a slow, steady, gradual response in the garden from my summer solstice (June 21) planting of tomatoes, peppers, eggplant, and cucumbers. I have been thinking a lot about the Art of Continuous Season Extension (ACSE). There is a lot of good information available about ACSE. For example, see the the book “The Four Season Farm Gardener’s Cookbook” by Eliot Coleman and Barbara Damrosch, published in 2011.
To give a short summary of ACSE, it is a method of extending the growing season, as well as a way to extend your harvest by using structures such as low tunnels (poly tunnels), high tunnels (hoop houses), cold frames, and greenhouses. The structures are typically used to protect plants from the cooler, wetter temperatures of the spring and fall, but they can also be used to protect plants from the heat and dryness of the summer. The structures are used in conjunction with

appropriate planting techniques, such as choosing cold-hardy varieties, using row covers, and implementing crop rotation.

It has also helped me protect my plants from extreme weather conditions, pests, and diseases. Additionally, ACSE promotes sustainability by reducing the need for artificial heating, cooling, and pest control methods.
In conclusion, I highly recommend learning about and implementing the Art of Continuous Season Extension in your own garden. It is a great way to maximize your harvest, protect your plants, and practice sustainable gardening methods.

continuation:
when you make history by locking up you diary with a man
by karra in diary of a girlfriend, diary of a single lady, just for fun, life and things, randomness Tags: diary, diary of a girlfriend, diary of a single lady, fun, life and things, randomness
I found this in the archives of my blog and I thought it was funny, so I decided to repost it. This was written by me on my blog when I was 17. The story is about a guy I met. He had a diary and I wanted to borrow it. So, he decided to lock it up with me. LOL!
One night, after I had a long day, I decided to go home from the college library. I got in my car and started to drive. When I got to the next street, I stopped at a red light. There was a guy standing by my car. He looked like he wanted to talk to me. I rolled down the window and he said, “Hey, do you want to borrow my diary?” I was surprised.
“You have a diary?” I asked.
“Yeah. I have been writing in it for a couple of
continuation_metric:
years now. It's like my best friend,” he replied.
I found it interesting and I wanted to read it. So, I agreed to borrow it from him. He opened the car door and handed me the diary.
“But there's one condition,” he said.
“What condition?” I asked curiously.
“You have to promise me that you won't tell anyone about what you read in my diary,” he said, looking serious.
“Alright, I promise,” I replied, not really understanding why it was such a big deal.
He then took out a small key and locked the diary.
“Why did you lock it?” I asked, slightly confused.
“It's my way of making sure that you keep your promise. No one will be able to read it unless I give them the key,” he explained.
I thought it was a bit strange but also kind of sweet. He entrusted me with something personal to him. So, I thanked him and we parted ways.
Later that night, when I got home, I unlocked the diary, curious to see what was inside. I read a few pages and it was filled with his thoughts, emotions, and experiences. It was like a window into his mind. I felt honored that he trusted me with his innermost thoughts.
And that's the story of how I made history by locking up someone's diary. It was a simple act, but it meant something to both of us.

prompt: the great train robbers
continuation:
the great train robbers (10)
How The Great Train Robbery Changed Film
A 1903 robbery set the scene for Hollywood’s first blockbuster.
The Great Train Robbery is the first feature-length narrative film. The movie, directed by Edwin S. Porter and made by Edison Studios, uses techniques such as parallel editing, cross-cutting, slow motion, and superimposition to tell a simple story of a train robbery, its aftermath, and its capture.
The movie premiered on August 16, 1903. It was released with a stereoscopic remake of the film, which allowed theater owners to charge patrons to view the film with 3D glasses.
The film was a massive success, and The Great Train Robbery became the first blockbuster film. It was a key film in the development of the American film industry.
For more, read The Great Train Robbery: How One Film Changed Hollywood and American Cinema by Scott Eyman.
Posted in Library of Congress, The Great Train Robbery, The Great Train Robbery changed film	| Tagged Library

In a couple of days, it will be a brand new year.
As the years go by, I am beginning to believe that the beginning of a new year doesn’t really mean anything. It’s just a marker that we set for ourselves.
The thing about markers is that they come with no guarantees.
They are not magical, and they do not offer any protection. They are just reminders, markers that have nothing to do with us, not at all. They are just an indication that something has been crossed, and we will continue on our way.

A great workout to lose weight is the famous "Tabata" workout. You can easily do it at home! It's a series of 4 minutes exercise (20 seconds on, 10 seconds off) with a recovery of 10-12 seconds. You can do it with any type of exercise (running, cycling, swimming, crossfit, power walking, jumping rope, etc) but the most common is the running and cycling.
It is important to know that you will be doing 8 rounds. That means that after doing 4 minutes of exercise you will be doing 4 minutes of rest. When the 8 rounds are finished you will have done 4 minutes of rest, and then you start over again.
The Tabata Method can help you burn fat. But it is also important to do it with the right intensity. If you are not going at 100% effort you will not get the results. The goal is to do all the rounds of 20 seconds of exercise and 10 seconds rest at 100% intensity.

In snatch theft, a person walks up to a person who has their hands in their pockets, backpack, or briefcase, and grabs the wallet, purse, or other object. The pickpocket then quickly leaves the scene.
In most cases, the pickpocket never gets caught. The victim is often too embarrassed or ashamed to report the theft, even if the amount of money taken is large. In other cases, the thief is caught, but the victim doesn't want to press charges.
In the United States, pickpocketing is also common on the subway or a crowded train or bus. Pickpockets hide in crowds of people and watch for unattended bags or other valuable objects that might be left in a crowded public place. When a pickpocket spots a potential victim, he or she will snatch the object from the victim's hands.
